topics.topic_description: Differentiating Machine Learning from traditional programming paradigms based on how rules and data are handled.
Identifying the primary goal and typical applications of Supervised Learning.
Understanding the concept of the 'Curse of Dimensionality' and its implications in Machine Learning.
Defining and identifying examples of discrete vs. continuous random variables.
Applying the product rule or sum rule of probability in a simple scenario.
Interpreting the meaning and application of Cross-Entropy or KL Divergence in the context of machine learning models.
Distinguishing between regression and classification problems based on the nature of the output variable.
Understanding the role of the learning rate in Gradient Descent and its impact on convergence.
Comparing Gradient Descent and the Normal Equation for linear regression, considering their computational complexity and applicability.
Differentiating between Maximum A Posteriori (MAP) and Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE).
Identifying the key assumption of the Na√Øve Bayes classifier (conditional independence).
Calculating Gini Index or Entropy for a given node in a decision tree to measure impurity.
Explaining the purpose of the Kernel Trick in SVMs for handling non-linear classification problems.
Identifying the visual characteristics and causes of overfitting in a machine learning model.
Comparing the strengths and weaknesses of K-Means, Hierarchical Agglomerative Clustering (HAC), and DBSCAN for different data characteristics.
